awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Corrosion Resistance of Nano-meter Graphene Coatings in Aggressive Microbial Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1454102
Gadhamshetty

CAREER: Corrosion Resistance of Nano-meter Graphene Coatings in Aggressive Microbial Environment

The annual costs for the direct and indirect effects of metallic corrosion on infrastructure have been reported to reach nearly $1 trillion in United States. Microbial corrosion accounts for nearly 20-40 % of the total corrosion costs. While there are several protective coatings available for metal protection, the commercial coatings tend to fail in the aqueous and microbial environments. The central goal of this project is to investigate a new class of minimally invasive (thickness of few nanometers), pin-hole-free, robust, and protective coatings made from conformal graphene for use against microbial corrosion. This CAREER project enables the rational design of the next generation of minimally invasive, nanometer-scale, microbial-corrosion resistant coatings featuring graphene building blocks. It will focus on four broader impact objectives: 1) to develop an Adobe-director-based virtual laboratory to provide students with hands-on tutorials on microbial corrosion/Gr experiments; 2) to integrate graphene research in undergraduate curriculum; 3) to encourage under-represented American Indians (from 9 SD reservations) to join BS and MS degrees; and 4) to work with educational experts to evaluate the educational/outreach activities.

This CAREER proposal seeks to make fundamental contributions in our understanding on why graphene works effectively under microbial conditions. Towards this end, the PI will use Desulfovibrio vulgaris as a model for sulfate-reducing bacteria to investigate the effectiveness of graphene-coatings under varying stimuli related to: i) electrochemical constraints, ii) physiological parameters, iii) the point defects in graphene, iv) wettability of graphene, v) cytotoxicity of graphene, and, vi) graphene-production techniques. In preliminary studies, a detailed electrochemical analysis revealed that the graphene offers ~100-fold improvement in microbial corrosion resistance compared to Parylene coatings, ~41-fold compared to bare graphene, and ~10-fold compared to polyurethane coatings. These findings shows a promise for microbial corrosion-resistant graphene coatings as their average thickness (1-2 nm) is 25-fold smaller than Parylene (40-50 nm), and 4000-fold smaller than polyurethane (20-80 micron). The microscopy and spectroscopy techniques revealed that the microbes observed in this study (e.g. Strenotrophomonas species within gammaproteobacteria) can attack polymers and induce micron-length tears leading to non-conformal polymer coatings, while the graphene coating was found to be electrochemically inert, extremely conformal, and resistant to microbial attack. The nano-scale graphene coatings also cause minimal changes to the underlying surface topology.

por.por_cntn:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) grant provided funding for PI Gadhamshetty to design and develop a new class of minimally invasive, two-dimensional (2D) coatings (thickness of few nanometers) for use against microbial corrosion (MIC). Protective coatings based on 2D graphene materials were evaluated on metal substrates exposed to sulfate reducing bacteria that is widely implicated in corrosion.

The intellectual merit of this project lied in assessing the effects of nanoscale surficial properties, including number of nanolayers and inherent defects (e.g., grain boundaries and vacancy defects), on performance of the coatings. A diverse range of methods based on electrochemistry, spectroscopy, and microscopy were developed and used to assess the  nanoscale properties. The broader societal impact of this project lies in enabling rational design and development of MIC resistant coatings featuring building blocks of graphene materials. These coatings showed 10-100-fold improvement in MIC resistance compared to commercial polymers. These outcomes can guide practical methods for synthesizing 2D coatings for protecting metals effectively from aggressive biological environments. This project supported a wide range of broader education and outreach objectives. Research training opportunities in 2D materials and bioelectrochemistry was provided to nine graduate students, including 3 females and a Native American grad student, undergraduate students, and high school teachers.  One of the students, Namita Shrestha that graduate with a PhD degree landed a tenure track faculty position; and others have taken positions as research scientists or engineers in the field. This project also resulted in 20 peer reviewed articles with students as authors and co-authors, in peer-reviewed journals including ACS Nano, Advanced Materials, Carbon and Water Research. Other research products included two patents, 5 book chapters, and over 25 presentations.

 To sustain the 2D materials research beyond the award duration, the PI leveraged promising findings on 2D coatings from this CAREER project (e.g., ACS Nano 12, 3, 2242?2252), developed visionary ideas, and collaborated with a diverse team of researchers to enable a state-wide virtual center entitled 2D-Materials for Biofilm Engineering, Science and Technology center (funded by NSF OIA#1849206 award). The findings were also leveraged to develop another research center titled Data Driven Material Discovery Center (NSF #OIA- 1849206). Using resources from the CAREER award and the two center-type awards, the PI?s team was able to to create a previously unavailable 2D-Materials Laboratory (2DML) at South Dakota Mines. This 2DML features the state-of-the art infrastructure for synthesis of 2D materials (e.g., graphene and hexagonal boron nitride) and characterization. Synthesis equipment include chemical vapor deposition and pulsed laser deposition equipment and characterization equipment include Confocal Raman microscopy.

The PIs team is currently developing a convergence research training framework that leverages transdisciplinary tools in 2D material science, artificial intelligence, and genome-to-phenome analysis tools. The long-term goal is to infuse transdisciplinary knowledge (bioscience, computer science and materials science and engineering) that enables next generation engineers and scientists to design high performance 2D coatings to protect underlying infrastructure from aggressive biological environments.   


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Venkata R Gadhamshetty
